text: Infection and replication of <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - human immunodeficiency viruses : genetic analyses of LTR and <extra_id_0> tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutations in primary and long-term human lymphoid cells .
<extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is an essential regulatory protein for the replication of human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) .
Mutations in the <extra_id_0> tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene have been shown to block HIV replication in human T cells .

Several studies have established that <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> releases an elongation block to the transcription of HIV long terminal repeat ( LTR ) ; however , it is not known whether this mechanism alone is sufficient to explain the block to HIV replication in human T cells when <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is absent .
It is possible that <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is also needed for other functions during HIV replication .

To test these hypotheses , we studied several <extra_id_0> tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutants , including two stop codon mutants and one deletion mutant using replication-competent HIV-1 constructs carrying wild-type or mutant LTRs with modifications in the NF-kappa B and / or <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding sites .

In this study , we show that <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - HIV-1 with wild-type LTRs can replicate in HeLa cells , and the virus produced from HeLa cells can infect primary peripheral blood lymphocytes and macrophages .

It was found that the propagation of the <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutants containing wild-type LTRs was less efficient than that of the LTR - modified <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutants .
Large amounts of viral RNA and particles were synthesized in infections established using the <extra_id_0> tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutants that contain modified LTRs .

However , this efficient propagation of the LTR - modified <extra_id_0> tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutants was restricted to some lymphoid cell lines that have been transformed with other viruses .

Thus , despite its essential role for releasing an elongation block , <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is not otherwise absolutely required for synthesis of full-length HIV transcripts and assembly of virus particles .

Direct sequencing of the viral genomes and reinfection kinetics showed no evidence of wild-type reversion even after prolonged infection with the <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - virus .
The implications for in vivo HIV-1 replication and potential application of this system to the study of alternative <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> function are discussed .
